stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses almost the entire stream on designing the "retro section"—the final area of Return to Yoshi's Island—while occasionally showcasing a separate, paid-commission hack (“drug Mario”). Most of the work involves laying out geometry, fixing UV maps, juggling memory limits, and deciding how to combine all 15 Mario 64 levels into one continuous course.

development_findings.summary: The final level will be a single, vertical ‘only-up’ style course that mashes together geometry from all 15 Mario 64 stages; players ascend through Bob-omb Battlefield, Lethal Lava Land, Jolly Roger Bay (with the submarine), etc., ending at Peach’s Castle with Yoshi handing out the star.
development_findings.quote: "It’s going to be every Mario 64 level at the same time… such a cool flex to see all of the levels at the same time."

development_findings.summary: Kaze intends the level to be completable without wing-cap or extended moves, but still reward creative skips; platform spacing, split sections, and flamethrower placement were adjusted live to balance difficulty and freedom.
development_findings.quote: "I want this game to be beatable without Mario's extended moveset… If you can do some skips, I'm fine with that, but if it just makes it completely trivial, I don't like that."

development_findings.summary: Severe N64 memory limits drive design: the retro area must stay inside a white bounding box to avoid rendering errors; remaining free space is roughly a quarter-megabyte, so detail is pared back and triangles culled aggressively.
He routinely fixes Nintendo’s original ‘shitty’ UV maps and allows minimal vertex coloring "only to emulate baked lighting" while otherwise keeping a deliberately vanilla aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: "I’m trying to make it slightly better than vanilla… I’m allowed to fix the UV maps, right?"

development_findings.summary: Backgrounds (skybox-style billboards) may replace walls in some sub-areas to free the camera and save geometry, inspired by Mario World 3’s parallax mountains.
Performance work: ROM is compiled with –O2, the ROM must be expanded, and segments may be moved behind the frame buffer when overflows are detected—proof Kaze’s custom memory-moving code is working.
Tool/tech stance: prefers Nemu and Project64 1.6, dislikes Parallel Launcher (claims its dev purposely breaks Kaze’s hacks).
Overworld will depict the whole of Yoshi’s Island, split into multiple areas for memory reasons; side courses and overworld still remain after the retro section.
Star tasks sketched: a squid-Yoshi’s house with a bit-pipe appears on Star 6; pyramid-top wing-cap lets players fly from ‘pillow to pillow’.

context_findings.summary: Kaze treats potential Nintendo takedowns as a win-win scenario: if removed, he will strip Nintendo IP, reskin assets (Mario→dinosaur hero, Bowser→crocodile) and sell it commercially.
context_findings.quote: "If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can rewrite it into my own game and sell it on Steam."

context_findings.summary: He shows little fear of legal action, asserting Nintendo doesn’t control global law and that he lacks enough clout for them to notice.
Personal schedule: parents visiting for 10 days and daughter’s baptism, so next streams are uncertain.
Self-awareness: he "forgets everything" when streaming—yapping empties short-term memory within seconds.
context_findings.quote: "When I'm yapping, I do not remember anything I say. After two seconds, it's just out of my brain."

biobak.summary: Created most of the level geometry for the separate ‘drug Mario’ commission; presence indicates Biobak still supplies large chunks of level art.

zeina.summary: Appears briefly in chat; Kaze notes they are currently hate-watching the anime Seven Deadly Sins together, hinting at shared downtime but no direct project work this stream.

key_stories.title: Pride-Flag Chess Level Controversy
key_stories.summary: A ‘Chess’ level featuring rainbow flags drew complaints that it unintentionally mocked the LGBT community. Kaze decides to redesign it as an anti-Bowser protest site using ‘All Koopas Are Bastards’ banners.
key_stories.challenge: Community feedback labeled the flag imagery offensive.
key_stories.process: On-stream discussion of alternative decals and converting flags to Bowser-themed protest art.
key_stories.outcome: Level will be censored/re-skinned to avoid misinterpretation.
key_stories.key_quote: "If we all perceive it to be offensive then that's bad. I'm thinking everything gets replaced with Bowser flags and ‘All Koopas Are Bastards’ stickers."

key_stories.title: Nintendo Takedown Contingency
key_stories.summary: Kaze openly plans for a possible DMCA. He would strip Nintendo code, reskin characters into original dinosaurs, rename the game ‘Return to Dinosaur Island,’ and launch on Steam.
key_stories.challenge: Constant risk of legal removal of Mario 64 ROM hacks.
key_stories.process: Designs assets generically so they can be swapped; discusses PR spin.
key_stories.outcome: Sees either outcome (hack lives or is removed) as advantageous.
key_stories.key_quote: "I'm not scared of the Nintendo ninjas… I'd just turn this into my own game and be richer."

key_stories.title: Memory Ceiling While Building the Retro Section
key_stories.summary: During live editing the retro course overshot N64 RAM limits. Kaze used his segment-shuffling code to move data behind the frame buffer and trimmed geometry.
key_stories.challenge: Running out of memory (only ~0.25 MB free).
key_stories.process: Checked segment sizes, deleted triangles, and verified automated overflow handling.
key_stories.outcome: Confirmed toolchain works; level now fits within bounds.
